subject: Art
title: Oil Painting Mediums
description: Linseed oil, turpentine, and specialized mediums that modify oil paint behavior.

hook.text: Oil paint straight from the tube has one consistency. Add linseed oil â€” it flows like silk. Add turpentine â€” it thins like watercolor. Add Liquin â€” it dries in a day instead of a week. Mediums transform the paint to match your needs.

buildup.text: Common mediums: linseed oil (adds fat, increases flow and gloss), turpentine/OMS (thins paint, speeds drying â€” for lean early layers), stand oil (thicker linseed, levels brushstrokes), Liquin (fast drying, increases flow), and damar varnish (for protective final coating).

discovery.text: A basic medium recipe: 1 part stand oil + 1 part turpentine (or OMS). This gives a smooth, medium-consistency paint that dries in 1-2 days. Adjust the ratio: more oil = fatter/slower, more solvent = leaner/faster.

twist.text: Modern solvent-free alternatives exist: walnut oil (replaces linseed), spike lavender oil (replaces turpentine), and water-mixable oil paints (clean up with water). Healthy oil painting is absolutely possible without toxic solvents.

climax.text: Try painting a stroke with: plain oil paint, paint + linseed oil (flowing), paint + turpentine (thin), and paint + Liquin (smooth). Each medium creates a different mark quality. The medium IS the technique.

punchline.text: Mastering oil painting is mastering mediums. The paint is the voice; the medium is the accent.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of adding linseed oil to oil paint?
options: To increase flow, add gloss, and make the paint fatter for upper layers
